multiplechoiceresponse.p: Let’s say you follow Option B.
You have 2 questions out of 20 that use advanced features, 1 each in topics 1 and 4. You want to randomise display of all your question but only require 12 in total to be shown to the learner.
multiplechoiceresponse.label: What structure will you need to follow for set up in your content library?

choicegroup.choice: Create one content library of all 20 questions and set display to 12 questions. What about those tricksy advanced questions? They can't go in the content library
Create one content library of 18 questions, excluding the advanced feature questions. Set display to 10 questions. Add two additional fixed questions with advanced features. Well done!

Create one content library of 18 questions, excluding the advanced feature questions. Set display to 12 questions. This is definitely one way of setting it up, if you don't want to use the advanced questions anymore

Create four separate content libraries. Topics 1 an 4 with 4 questions and topics 2 and 3 with 5 questions. Set content libraries of topics 1 and 4 to display 3 questions each in the course assessment, and topics 2 and 3 to display 4 questions each. Create two additional fixed questions in edX studio for the quiz. Not strictly wrong but the more complex setup, using option C and separating out each topic

demandhint.hint: Totally understandable if you just want to be told the answer! Clue = 2 must be fixed as they are advanced so that leaves 10 to play with...
